label: Letter 2 from Sidney Jennings Legendre, July 28, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, lamenting how long it is taking her to go to England, advising her on what to do for their children, and recounting the events of an evening spent at the Outrigger beach club. Sidney continues in his letter to list all the people he has dined with, comparing the benefits of swimming versus playing tennis, and discussing the warm climate of Hawaii and the recent war news. This letter is a copy; the original was sent to London.

original to London
July 28, 1943
Dear Gertie,
The mystery thickens and I am more thrilled and
excited than ever. This departure of yours is as I said
before[,]better than any detective sotry. I rushed home from
the office on Monday to receive your telephone call and
found your cable under the door, saying that you had postponed
it. As this came on top of the news of Mussolinis resignation
I judged that the two were connected somhow. I should
think that you would be nervous as a fiddle trying to find
out whether you are to go or not. The idea of the slow
transportation is firghtful. Why you can become an old
women before you ever arrive. This I do know. You will
undoubtly be kept in Washington until the hot weather is
passed and will arrive in your new post just in time for the
bad winter weather. In other words it will be so arranged
by fate that you will get the worst of both places. Could'nt
you arrange it so that you go up and stay with the children
at Watch Hill until the Goverment ma es up its mind. There
is no use sweating out the last of your energy in Washington
if you are leaving it. You probably need a rest very badly,
and I know the children would love to see you if it is at
all possible to go up.. Your discripti n of BO Bo charms me so
th t I have re[a]d it sev ral times. she must be the cutiest
th ng in existence and I am terribly sorry that I will miss
seeing herx during these wonderful years when she is chubby
and huggable. It is wonderful that Landine is becoming free
and easy. Nothing you ever have done with the children pleased
me as much as your dismissing Madmofselle. I felt that if she
was with Landine two more years the child would be ruined beyo-
nd help. A few years with Miss Evans, and making her own bedx
etc. will work wonders.
Morris and I and Johnny Lee went to the Outrigger
Club for a swim and dinner tonight. It is the first time I
have been there for at least two weeks. It was very gay
as a new law has been passed that you can drink until seven
oclock at all bars and clubs. Of co[u]rse the world was taking
advantage of this fact as the law only went into effect
last night. I wish I could tell you that we had girls with us
and were the gayest of all. However it is the same old
story. We had dinner, finished, Morris arose and said lets
go to the movies. Johhny w[A]s a little upset and suggested
watching the dancing, but yielded when Morris said he w[A]s going
to the mov[i]es and I said I w[A]s comming home to write to you.
You menti[o]ned in your last letter that I never told you about
go[i]ng to the Marxs for a Luau. If you will look back
through your letters you will see that I listed several times
[End Page 1]
the places that I have been to dinner.
Once to the Marxs
Twice to the Moddys
Once to the Wilders
Once to Gregg Merrils.
Once to that old Colonel,a friend of Olives, I have forgotte
his name
Once to Duke Kahanmoku
But sweetheart even if I don't remember to tell you, what is
there wrong about that. At thirty nine one should be able to
go out to dinner without sitting down and immediately reporting
it to ones wife.
I played tennis with Morris again yesteeday, and we
both loved it. It is an entirely different form of exercise
from swimming and leaves you with a wonderful rested[,]exercised
feeling. Swimming on the other hand leaves you pouped andpl yed
out. I think this is due to the warm water and also to the
fact that if you lie in et r for a long time as you do on
a s rboard it relaxes your muscles to a point where their
ability to contract is gone. I have always felt like a limp
rag after swimming but after tennis and a shower it is almost
like old times.
It has become very arm here now and we work without
ties and everyones shirt is wringing wet druing theday. This
of course is an old story to you who have been laboring in
terr fic heat for months but it is so unusal out ehre that
we all talk of it. I do not re lly su pose the temperature
changes very much but we re so spoiled by the climate and
beauty of the place that little things are noticed.
I wish Icould be optomistic about the fut re of the
war. You cannot believe wh t yo read in the papers and maga-
zines. According to them Jap ships ndplanes go down by the
thousands, their fight[ers]are swept formt he f ce of the e rth
and noth ng happens to our equipment or warriors. And you
know M ssolini r signing does not necess rily mean that Italy
will quit. She may count on our never intending to invade her
but rather to push up the Adriatic, bypassing her land. In this
case she has nothing to gain by surrending and everything togain
by remaining in the war. However the resignation is a boon
to one class of people, the commentators. They are never off
the radio with their speculations, prophsies and warnings.
They are race unto themselves, half Gen[e]rals, Admirals, Fianances
welded together with the essence of the common people.
Katherine wrote me that you had been there and how
much she had loved seeing you. She described how you had a 
mint julep before dinner and then tennis next day and it made
me very homesick for th[A]t last wonderful week end when the entire
family was un ted and we laughed so at Morris dragging Nancy
behind in the little wagon and Armant and Fifi pedalling like
mad to the village and returning exhausted.
[End Page 2]
You and I w lked and played tennis together, As you
described we slept in the room overlooking the river and
came down very l te for breakfast Sunday morning, and as
I remember we had rasberries and thick cream and all sorts of 
good things. Katherine is wonderful to keep theplace
going, and I bet she works her guests to the bone in payment f
for food and lodging.
Goodbye sweetheart, let me know where you are
and what your plans are. W[i]th all my love.
Sidney J. Legendre
[End Page 3]
